titlestmt.titleproper: Belt (Elmer) Collection of Vinciana Graphic Arts
Finding Aid for the Elmer Belt Collection of Vinciana Graphic Arts LSC.2366
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Kelly Besser, 2020.

p.date: Online finding aid last updated 2020 December 18.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-06-06 13:59:39 -0700.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is in English, French, German, Italian, and Latin.

did.unittitle: Elmer Belt collection of Vinciana graphic arts
did.abstract: The Elmer Belt collection of Vinciana graphic arts is a special collection of original artwork, original printed lithographs, and materials concerning Leonardo da Vinci and the Italian Renaissance. It was donated to UCLA in 1961 by Dr. Elmer Belt, Professor Emeritus in the UCLA School of Medicine and a collector of Vinciana for more than sixty years.
did.physloc: Held at UCLA Library Special Collections. Advance notice is required for access to the collection. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.
did.langmaterial: Materials are in English, French, German, Italian, Latin, and Russian.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Reproduction and Use
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Elmer Belt collection of Vinciana graphic arts (Collection 2366). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices. Processed by UCLA Library Preservation and Conservation Department, 2020. Additional description by Kelly Besser and Tess Livesley-O'Neill in 2020.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Problematic Content and Description in UCLA's Library Collections and Archives.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Elmer Belt, M.D. (1893-1980), was a Los Angeles area urologist, bibliophile, and humanist who was instrumental in the founding of the School of Medicine, University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA). An avid book collector, Dr. Belt became an expert on Leonardo da Vinci and his time, amassing a large and important collection of books and other material related to da Vinci's life and work. He donated this collection to UCLA in 1961. Born Arthur Elmer Belt in Chicago, Illinois on April 10, 1893, his family moved to Los Angeles when he was nine and then to a small ranch in Orange County near Anaheim. Elmer Belt (the form of name he preferred) entered Los Angeles High School in 1907 and enrolled in Latin, a medical school prerequisite. There he met Ruth Smart whom, he said, he "never subsequently permitted out of my sight." The two were married in 1918. Dr. Belt began collecting books as a student in 1909 with works by Upton Sinclair; in 1934 he became involved with Sinclair's campaign for governor of California. The Upton Sinclair collection was eventually donated to Occidental College. Dr. Belt attended the University of California at Berkeley, obtaining a B.A. in 1916 and an M.A. in 1917. He attended the University of California Medical School in San Francisco and was chosen as a fellow of the Hooper Institute for Medical Research, working with Dr. George Whipple and Dr. Frank Hinman. After finishing medical school in 1920 Dr. Belt continued working in urology with Dr. Hinman. Early in his medical school career, Dr. Belt signed up for a non-credit elective course in the History of Medicine taught by Dr. George Washington Corner, an anatomist who had recently come to the University of California from Johns Hopkins University. It was in this class that Dr. Belt developed his fascination with and devotion to Leonardo da Vinci, inspiring the vast library of Vinciana he eventually donated to UCLA. Subsequently his collecting fervor also included Silas Weir Mitchell and Florence Nightingale and in the 1930s Dr. Belt began working with Los Angeles bookseller Jake Zeitlin to fulfill these and other ambitious collecting interests. After a year as Resident in Urology with Dr. Hinman in San Francisco, Dr. Belt spent a year as Resident in General Surgery at Boston's Peter Bent Brigham Hospital, working under Dr. Harvey Cushing. In 1923, the Belts moved to Los Angeles where Elmer began a private practice. He soon established the Elmer Belt Urologic Group, a group practice which moved to its own building on Wilshire Boulevard in 1936; the upper floor of this structure housed his ever-expanding library. From 1939 through 1954 Belt served as the President of the State Board of Public Health, having been first appointed by California Governor Culbert Olsen and then reappointed by Governor Earl Warren for each of Warren's three terms in office. Dr. Belt had privileges as a staff, attending, or consulting urologist at many hospitals around Los Angeles County and taught as Clinical Professor of Surgery (Urology) in the UCLA School of Medicine. He was instrumental in the founding of the UCLA School of Medicine and finding its first dean, and continued as its staunch supporter throughout his life. Elmer Belt died on May 17, 1980 at age 87.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Elmer Belt collection of Vinciana graphic arts is a special collection of original artwork, original printed lithographs, and materials concerning Leonardo da Vinci and the Italian Renaissance. It was donated to UCLA in 1961 by Dr. Elmer Belt, Professor Emeritus in the UCLA School of Medicine and a collector of Vinciana for more than sixty years.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The arrangement of materials maintains their existing order.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Elmer Belt papers (Collection 0066). Available at Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library History and Special Collections for the Sciences, UCLA.

Charles Huggins collection of material about and correspondence with Elmer Belt and Willard E. Goodwin (Collection 0043). Available at Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library History and Special Collections for the Sciences, UCLA.
Jake Zeitlin papers (Collection 0334). Available at UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.
John Allison Benjamin papers (Collection 0001). Available at Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library History and Special Collections for the Sciences, UCLA.
Kate Traumann Steinitz papers (Collection 1770). Available at UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.
Library. Arts Library. Publications. (Collection 0164). Available at UCLA Library Special Collections, University Archives, University of California, Los Angeles.
Mae Babitz papers (Collection 1740). Available at UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.

Sir William Osler Portrait by Seymour Thomas and Other Osler-Related Papers (Collection 0181). Available at Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library History and Special Collections for the Sciences, UCLA.
Willard E. Goodwin papers (Collection 0573). Available at UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.

physdesc.physfacet: Italian drawing. After the Antique. Red chalk.

physdesc.dimensions: Height left 12.8 cm; height right 12 cm. Width top: 12 cm; bottom: 12.8 cm.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Acquired at Hauswedell, Hamburg 1956 as "Milanese drawing."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Watermark: Possibly drawn after the Roman Horse in Naples. Attributed to Melzi in 1967 by Carlo Pedretti.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.p: Barbara Bacall, A catalogue of the drawings of Leonardo da Vinci and his school in the United States of America, M.A. thesis, UCLA, 1968; Carlo Pedretti, Leonardo da Vinci: studies for a Nativity and the 'Mona Lisa Cartoon' with drawings after Leonardo from the Elmer Belt Library of Vinciana: exhibition in honour of the Elmer Belt, M.D. on the occasion of his eightieth birthday (Los Angeles: UCLA, 1973) (UCLA Center for Medieval and Renaissance Studies. Publication Number 6), pp. 39f.

physdesc.physfacet: Italian drawings. After da Vinci. Pen and brown ink over very light lead point.

physdesc.dimensions: Top: 5.6 x 10.5 cm; bottom: 4.6 x 10.3 cm.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Fowles, 1969.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Leonardo's originals were in the collection of the Duke of Devonshire at Chatsworth; original Leonardo of lower left figure purchased by Getty Museum in 1984. Formerly a part of a set of twelve in the collection of the Earl of Pembroke at Wilton House.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two fragments in one mount. Each fragment contains two grotesque heads facing each other in profile. Counterimage of upper right figure in Conte de Caylus (q.v.) No. 25.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.p: F[rances] F[inger] in UCLA Librarian 22(2)(February 1969):7-9; S.A. Strong, Reproductions in facsimile of the drawings by the Old Masters in the collection of the Earl of Pembroke and Montgomery at Wilton House...(London, 1900), Part II, no. 15; Pedretti (op.cit.in I.1) p. 40.

physdesc.physfacet: Italian drawing. Brown pen and ink on brown paper, heightened with white.
Italian drawing. After da Vinci. Crayon and red chalk.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Left below the ink: 104. Right below: collector's mark. Verso: Stamp of V.F. der Collection Federn (Lugt 923) and in fine ink script: Nov.6-046-la. Below the Federn stamp a pale red stamp: V.M. Left along upper half of page: Leonardo da Vinci. In the middle of the fold: 277'. The verso shows that the leaf was once folded. Upper: Study after Dioscurides of the Quirinal. Lower: Studies of baroque baldacchino columns. Attribution: Carlo Pedretti.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.p: Bacall (op.cit. in I.1).

physdesc.physfacet: Italian drawing. Sepia. Watermark, Left: 1431 Right: Belt no. 55-307.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Verso: handwritten address: "All'ill R Y...al sig Cardinale d'Este Modena" Stripe of paper attached to lower margin with signature: "Ghezzi."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On one page with five drawings. Drawing one of five.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On one page with five drawings. Drawing two of five.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On one page with five drawings. Drawing three of five.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On one page with five drawings. Drawing four of five.

physdesc.physfacet: French drawing. Pencil and gray wash.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On one page with five drawings. Drawing five of five.

physdesc.physfacet: French drawing. After portrait in the editio princeps (1651) of the Trattato della pittura.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Collection Seeborger; Eric Bifferd; Jules Dapan sale Paris 1840; gift of Robert Schadt, curator, Huntington Library.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Atelier Degas, 4 et derniere vente, Paris, Galeries George Petit, July 2-4, 1919, no.85b (repr.); acquired by B. Degenhart in Munich, 1949 or 1951, for the Belt Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Inscribed in upper right-hand corner in pencil: "Florence 1869. Leonardo da Vinci." In lower left-hand corner is the red stamp Degas of the Durand Duel inventory after Degas' death. J. Rewald dates 1860, but Degas was in Italy in 1869.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.p: K.T. Steinitz, in Raccolta Vinciana XX(1964):387-390, fig. 1; Pedretti (op. cit. in I.1), pp. 43ff.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Monogram at left corner: "JR". Cut sharply at frameline.

bibliography.head: Bibliography

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.p: Bartsch XX p. 82 No.8.

physdesc.dimensions: 10.5 x 8 cm, matted on 23 x 17.6 cm

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Inscribed NEDIMEON [sic: Endimion]. Signed on plate F.P. On verso penciled reference: Mazzuoli 1320 (F.P.) B.20 [=Bartsch XX]. F.P. refers to the signature on the plate. Aus dem Kupferstich-Kabinett des Fuersten Waldburg Wolfegg (according to stamp and penciled note on verso of the print). Sale of duplicates 1902/1903.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.p: Bartsch XVI p. 25 No. 2; cf. pp. 4f. on FP.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mounted on blue. Signed on plate, the letters appearing reversed on the print. On verso: Stamp. Fuerstl. Waldburg Wolffeggsches Kupferstichkabinett (Lugt, Supplement No. 2542, p. 476). Below: B2 gegenseitig 117. Above in pencil: 161-321.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.p: Bartsch XVI pp. 6f. No. 2.

did.langmaterial: Materials are in French and English.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: The Death of Leonardo da Vinci

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cut and mounted on stationery paper. On verso a handwritten poem on widow-burning in India. Right: Walker sculp. Top: European magazine. Below: The Death of Leonardo de Vincay, publ. Sep. 1 1784 by Fielding, Paternoster Row (London) L. Sewell, Cornhill & I. Debrett, Picadilly.

did.unittitle: Portrait of Benvenuto Cellini with hat

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Taken from a book printed in England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cut sharp at frameline. Portrait in an oval within an elaborate cartouche with inscription: Franciscvs ex Principibus / Etruriae. The portrait represents a young man in armor with a lace collar.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.p: J. Bialostocki, European painting in Polish collections, describes as after a portrait by Velasquez in Modena, Bibl. Estense; cf. Wittkower, Bernini catalogue, no. 54.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: No. 2 of first edition. Marked on plate HM, the number of the first edition of 1785 (Verga No. 50). On each leaf, upper right corner, in pencil, the date 1842.

did.unittitle: Profile study of a man's head

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two studies of man's profile, the left one with proportion lines possibly derived from Leonardo; above at the second head, on a white band: "Eines Mannes Haupt." Between the heads, centered, a small cartouche touching the lower margin; with date and monogram: 1542 HS B.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.p: Gustav Pauli, Hans Sebald Beham: ein kritisches Verzeichnis seiner Kupferstiche, Radirungen und Holzschnitte (Strassburg: Heitz, 1901) III: 320; Bartsch VIII p. 211 No. 219.

did.unittitle: Caricature head, engraved in a circle within a square

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Left: Leonardo da Vinci. Right: De la Collection du Prince Charles de Ligne. Below: Dedie a ma femme. Engraved inscription around the circle: "Leonardo de Vinci de la collection du Prince de Ligne."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Italian. Unattributed: Casolani.

did.unittitle: Florence, ca. 1550. A pictorial map of the walled city.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mounted on gray and matted 54 x 69 cm. Top, centered: Fiorenza [letter z in reverse]. Left: Medici coat of arms. Right: Florentine fleur-de-lis within small cartouche. In foreground the river with the word: Arno. 5 cm. to lower margin: list of 60 buildings numbered according to numbers on map.

did.unittitle: Series of three small handcolored maps

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: VII.2 Brescia VII.3 Cremona VII.4 Ferrara

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Title in cartouche at left: Ducatus / Mediolanen / sis, finitima- / rumq 3 regionv / descriptio, avc- / tore Ioanne Ge- / orgio Septalia mediola / nense. / Top right: Sforza coat of arms. Verso: printed: p. 76 of Ortelius atlas 1670: Le Duche de Milan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Title in decorative cartouche: Domino / Fioren / tino. Left lower corner: small cartouche with coat of arms with dedication to "D. Theodoro Hasselaer. Scala di Mielia quindici." Between map and frameline a band with measurements. Represents Tuscany west of Florence with Empoli and Vinci.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Old hand coloring. Above right within a garlanded vignette: Ducatus / Tyronensis / perlustratus e descriptus ab / Isaaco Franco, Aedili Regia / et in ea provincia viarum magistro / (line) Touraine. Above left: (...Below left: Scale within a vignette. Gallica commune: Right below: Apud Guiljelmia et Johannem Blaew Amsteldami. On verso: printed text with titles: Ducatvs / Tvorenensis / vulgo Duche de Touraine.

did.unittitle: Reproduction of Mappamondo Catalano della Estense

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Modern (lithographic?) reproduction of circa 1375 piece.

physdesc.physfacet: Italian engraving. After Leonardo da Vinci.

physdesc.dimensions: 30.5 x 20 cm. Impression: 35 x 25.2 cm. on 57 x 40.5 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Below left: From the original drawing by Leonardo da Vinci. Below right: Engraved by Fl Bartolozzi, R.A. Historical Engraver to his Majesty. Below middle: In His Majesty's Collection published as the act directs...1796 by Chamberlaine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original creator: Leonardo da Vinci.

did.unittitle: Mort de Leonard de Vinci peint par Ingres, grave par Richemine.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Copy 2 acquired in Rome in 1969 by Kate Traumann Steinitz and donated to the library.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Imprime et publie par Goupl et Cie. Paris, London, Berlin, Verlag von Goupil et Cie. New York, published by M. Knoedler. 2 copies. With: Announcement of the sale of the painting, signed and dedicated to Alexander von Humboldt, 1881.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: VII.15 Noce de Cana. 5 x 5.5 cm (L.295) VII.16 Le repas chez le Parisien. (L.296) VII.17 Super d'Emaus. 5 x 5.4 cm (L.288) VII.18 La Cene. (X)

Presentation tipped in at left margin: "To Dr. Elmer Belt, great Vincian and great friend this triumph of Jacques Callot done in Florence in 1619. Herbert M. Evans." Paris: Chez Jean, rue Jean de Beauvais, no. 32.

physdesc.physfacet: Italian engraving. After Leonardo da Vinci.

did.unittitle: Leonardo da Vinci, portrait within an oval.
did.langmaterial: Materials are in Italian and German.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Claudio Artaria inc. "All'Egregio Gautero della Belle Arte / II Sig.re Bartolomeo Turina / questa sua pro-izia / " Verlag Gebruder Rocca in Berlin und Goettingen. Gedruckt von Hampe. The portrait is almost identical with the one signed Bossi and Anderloni, but 0.5 cm wider.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An engraving after Leonardo signed: "Leonardo Vinci (invit?) at bottom left of engraving. London (c1671-1707). Original and photoprint.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Signed Bossi and Anderloni.

physdesc.physfacet: Italian engraving. After Leonardo da Vinci.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Lionardo di Ser Piero / da Vinci [coat of arms] pittore / Scultore, Architetto &c / nato nel MCCCCXLV. morto nel MDXX [sic] Dedicato al...Mse, el Cavre Alessandro Coppoli Patrizio Perugino, e Fiorentino. / Preso da un Quadro esistente nella Galleria di S.A.R. di Firenze. Below: Correct life data written in pencil.

physdesc.physfacet: German engraving. After Leonardo da Vinci.

physdesc.dimensions: 19 x 28 cm (Margins cropped except for bottom) on 22 x 28 cm.

did.langmaterial: Materials are in French and German.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Left: a Paris chez Dopler, rue St. Jacques No. 21. Right: Roemhild sc. Depose. Below within decorative scrolls: "La Cene-Das Abendmahl / En verite, je vous dis un de vous doit me livrer--In Wahreit ich sage Euch, Einer von Euch wird mich verrathen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Below, centered: Engraved by W. Radclyffe. "Christ disputing with the doctors" / from the original Painting by Leonardo da Vinci in the National Gallery / No. 33 / Jones [and] Co of the Temple of the Muses, Finsbury Square, London.

did.unittitle: Leonardo da Vinci after a picture by himself engraved by Raffaello Morghen

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: London. Published by Charles Knight [and] Co. Ludgate St.

physdesc.physfacet: French drawing. Red chalk over ink.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Inscription: "From coll. Le Sueur. Enterrement et mort de Raphael. Son corps est porte a la sepulture par les principaux eleves; son tableaux de la Transfiguration suit la marche est porte en triumph de lui.

did.unittitle: Caricatures after Leonardo da Vinci and Hieronymus Bosch

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Acquired in 1951 at Colnaghi in London as Ghezzi or Zenetti, but identified by B. Degenhart as Baccio del Banco.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Supplements a set in the Staatliche Graphische Sammlung, Muenchen. This copy carries the number 139. The Munich set shows consecutive numbers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Inscribed at bottom: "La tour de la Bibliotheque Vinci 57."

did.unittitle: Portrait of Leonardo da Vinci with a cap

physdesc.dimensions: 30 x 24 cm. Impression: 38 x 30 cm on 40 x 32 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cartouche in imitation of embroidery, carrying the inscription: Leonardo / de Vinci. Left: L. de Vinci pinx. Right: J.M. Leroux sc. Center: B. Denoyer del. Below: "Il naquit en 1452 au Chateau de Vinci pres de Florence/Peintre, Architecte et Sculpteur, Il fut invite par Francois 1er a se rendre en France/il y vint en 1515 et mourut a Ambroise au palais de Clou le 2 mai, 1519. Publie par Veith [and] Hauser, Paris." Below: depose a la direction. Left: Imprime par Chardin aine et Asc.

physdesc.physfacet: Italian engraving. After Leonardo da Vinci.

physdesc.dimensions: 24.5 x 29 cm. Impression: 30 x 22 cm on 41.5 cm x 32.8 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Water stains. Left: Leonardus Vincius se ipsum pincit. Right: Raphael Morghen sculpsit.

did.unittitle: Salome with head of John the Baptist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Below left: Bernardino Luini dip. Below right: Giovita Garavaglia inc. Center: Pietro Anderloni dec. "All Egregio Protettore delle Belle Arti/xxx il originale esiste presso il Cav. Prof. Scarpa." In Firenze presso Luigi Bardi.
